oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Current Approaches to Internal Parasite Control in Food Animals
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Craig, Thomas M.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: internal parasites
food animals
anthelmintic
animal management
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The current concept on control of internal parasites of food animals should be just that, control. When an anthelmintic is used, individual animals are usually dewormed and then placed back into the same or a similar environment from whence they came. Even if hundreds of thousands of parasites were killed by the administration of the anthelmintic the billions of infective larvae in the environment were not and, within a short time, the animal may very well be as heavily infected as before. Some knowledge of the biology of the parasites, the specificity and spectrum of the anthelmintic, and the management and goals of the herd, flock or drove manager is necessary to control parasites.
